Hi EdTanous

This patch looks good, thank you
why to add loadCertificate() here in app?
Because we need to be able to re-init the SSL context from within an HTTP handler.  (see where this patchset does that in account_service.hpp).
Done
why to remove these headers?
Because I was here anyway, and it seemed like a good idea to implement the TODO.
Done

So since you still add a cookie I assume you want to allow web browsers to use mTLS to authenticate to bmcweb. But AFAICT you still need CSRF protection in this case or else a malicious unrelated tab in a web browser with that client certificate would be able to covertly run any requests any time.
I might be missing something but it looks that getting mTLS with web-browsers done right security wise requires much more effort and then would be out of scope for this patch if at all possible (without additional authentication factors).
Probably mTLS for web browsers should be declared unsupported in this patch, no cookies sent at all and then if a good solution found re-introduced later? And if there's a reasonable way then probably getting WebSockets working can be done too?
Either way to me it looks like this part requires more clarifications so that even someone inexperienced with web like me could follow the ideas behind security of the solution.

> So since you still add a cookie I assume you want to allow web browsers to use mTLS to authenticate to bmcweb.

Today, this use case doesn't work, although was implemented at one point.  I have left the cookie in case someone in the future wants to use it, but to my knowledge, webui-vue has never supported it.

> But AFAICT you still need CSRF protection in this case or else a malicious unrelated tab in a web browser with that client certificate would be able to covertly run any requests any time.
> I might be missing something but it looks that getting mTLS with web-browsers done right security wise requires much more effort and then would be out of scope for this patch if at all possible (without additional authentication factors).


Yep, you got it.  Trying to get web browsers working with mtls is outside this patch, and would need someone to champion it.

> Probably mTLS for web browsers should be declared unsupported in this patch, no cookies sent at all and then if a good solution found re-introduced later?

The difference in what you're asking is the IsAuthenticated header?  If we wanted to remove that, lets do it in a different patch.  I believe it's still used in some contexts.  The cookies are not.

> And if there's a reasonable way then probably getting WebSockets working can be done too?

A code review isn't the place for that discussion.  That would be a new feature.

> Either way to me it looks like this part requires more clarifications so that even someone inexperienced with web like me could follow the ideas behind security of the solution.

what clarifications are you looking for?

> what clarifications are you looking for?

Let me try to rephrase. I have an impression that (presuming bmcweb should be secure by default) the right way to solve the TODO would be to disable sending of all cookies, including isAuthenticated, to discourage webui developers from trying to use mTLS altogether because with bmcweb as it currently is can not be made secure anyhow as it lacks any kind of CSRF protection for mTLS connections (I couldn't find any specific guidance about this aspect of mTLS at OWASP but it's essentially the same as basic auth, if you allow basic auth for web browser you need CSRF protections).

And in any case when a code is touched which has security implications it would be nice to see what rationale, what idea was behind the decision to make it the way it is. In this case you decided to leave the code sending the cookie as it was but it's not clear whether you considered security implications of that or not. If you see a practical way how webui can be improved to start using it without compromising security, an outline would be nice to have in a commit message. If you think that's not possible then why keep the dead code which can also encourage frontend developers to try using it without knowing it shouldn't be done?

> > what clarifications are you looking for?
> 
> Let me try to rephrase. I have an impression that (presuming bmcweb should be secure by default) the right way to solve the TODO would be to disable sending of all cookies, including isAuthenticated,

Sorry to cut in the middle of a sentence, but IsAuthenticated has no impact on the service security.  It is only a "hint" to the UI for the first load that it probably doesn't need to display the login page.

> to discourage webui developers from trying to use mTLS altogether because with bmcweb as it currently is can not be made secure anyhow as it lacks any kind of CSRF protection for mTLS connections 
> (I couldn't find any specific guidance about this aspect of mTLS at OWASP but it's essentially the same as basic auth, if you allow basic auth for web browser you need CSRF protections).

I'm not sure why you think they're similar, but they're really not similar at all, aside from the browser keeping a cache of each.  At a minimum, MTLS certificates have a valid by date and valid before date, that limit the exposure if they're leaked.  The certificate key itself is also never present on the wire as it is in basic auth.

If you're going to make statements about the security or non-security of bmcweb, please try to quote an authority on the subject (it doesn't have to be owasp).  Debating complex undocumented security principles in a code review isn't generally fruitful in my experience.

There are plenty of deployments where CSRF isn't necessarily required for MTLS, and to my knowledge, CSRF has never been enforced on a mutual TLS gui or in bmcweb, so that would be new, that I'm happy to discuss in a patches that want to add that.


The goal here isn't to encourage or discourage developers from doing anything.  If someone wants the webui to work with mutual TLS, they'll find a way to make it work and test it.  I haven't seen that happen, so the best I can do here is _try_ to keep the code similar for the paths that used to work.


> 
> And in any case when a code is touched which has security implications it would be nice to see what rationale, what idea was behind the decision to make it the way it is.

That's certainly something I try to ask for in reviews.  You are welcome to do it as well, although in this case, this was literally just removing extra things that were known to not be used (hence the TODO).  It didn't really have anything to do with security. 


> In this case you decided to leave the code sending the cookie as it was but it's not clear whether you considered security implications of that or not.

You mean the IsAuthenticated cookie?  That cookie has nothing to do with security, which is why it's not documented in the commit message.

> If you see a practical way how webui can be improved to start using it without compromising security, an outline would be nice to have in a commit message.

That would be for putting in a commit message in a patch about improving the webui, or a mailing list discussion.  Any "practical way" i suggest would start by reading information on the topic of mutual TLS authenticated websites and APIs, but that's something anyone can do.

> If you think that's not possible then why keep the dead code which can also encourage frontend developers to try using it without knowing it shouldn't be done?

Why wouldn't we encourage developers to add new things or fix bugs in existing implementations?
The code all looks nice but I do have a question about that cookie...
I think you might want to specify `Path=/` here or else multiple cookies with the same name are going to be created and even though it wouldn't be breaking anything (I guess) that's not intended.

> I think you might want to specify `Path=/`

That's fair, and based on our previous conversations correct, but that would be a different patch (along with a commit message describing why).

> here or else multiple cookies with the same name are going to be created and even though it wouldn't be breaking anything (I guess) that's not intended.

Hello,

During testing of the current bmcweb I noticed this IsAuthenticated cookie doesn't actually make it to the client, please see this debug log (with few messages added):

```
[DEBUG http_connection.hpp:104] 0x264cf58 Generated TLS session: 3PkjVDCcEr
[DEBUG http_connection.hpp:486] 0x264cf58 doReadHeaders
[DEBUG http_connection.hpp:498] 0x264cf58 async_read_header 116 Bytes
[DEBUG authentication.hpp:193] Adding cookie to response: 0x264f180
[DEBUG authentication.hpp:199]  TLS session: 3PkjVDCcEr with cookie will be used for this request.
[DEBUG authentication.hpp:279] authHeader=
[DEBUG http_connection.hpp:445] 0x264cf58 No content length available
[INFO http_connection.hpp:270] Request:  0x264cf58 HTTP/1.1 GET /redfish/v1/AccountService/Accounts 172.40.1.4
[DEBUG http_connection.hpp:303] Setting completion handler
[DEBUG http_response.hpp:270] 0x25ded40 setting completion handler
[DEBUG routing.hpp:650] Matched rule '/redfish/v1/AccountService/Accounts/' 1 / 2
[DEBUG dbus_privileges.hpp:50] userName = root userRole = priv-admin
[DEBUG query.hpp:125] setup redfish route
[DEBUG http_response.hpp:281] 0x25ded40 releasing completion handlertrue
[DEBUG http_response.hpp:270] 0x25ded40 setting completion handler
[DEBUG http_response.hpp:260] 0x25ded40 calling completion handler
[DEBUG http_response.hpp:263] 0x25ded40 completion handler was valid
[DEBUG query_param.hpp:1039] Processing query params
[DEBUG http_response.hpp:79] Moving response containers; this: 0x264f180; other: 0x25ded40
[DEBUG http_response.hpp:84] this header: Set-Cookie IsAuthenticated=true; Secure
[DEBUG http_response.hpp:90] that header: Allow GET, HEAD, POST
[DEBUG http_response.hpp:90] that header: OData-Version 4.0
[DEBUG http_response.hpp:90] that header: Link </redfish/v1/JsonSchemas/ManagerAccountCollection.json>; rel=describedby
```

In other words, the response (including the header that sets the cookie) gets fully overwritten during move after processing, naturally, it's not present in the reply a client sees:

```
< HTTP/1.1 200 OK
< Allow: GET, HEAD, POST
< OData-Version: 4.0
< Link: </redfish/v1/JsonSchemas/ManagerAccountCollection.json>; rel=describedby
< Strict-Transport-Security: max-age=31536000; includeSubdomains
< Pragma: no-cache
< Cache-Control: no-store, max-age=0
< X-Content-Type-Options: nosniff
< ETag: "45C7E789"
< Content-Type: application/json
* TLSv1.2 (IN), TLS header, Supplemental data (23):
< Date: Thu, 18 Jul 2024 10:57:46 GMT
< Content-Length: 395
<
{ 
  "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/AccountService/Accounts",
  "@odata.type": "#ManagerAccountCollection.ManagerAccountCollection",
  "Description": "BMC User Accounts",
  "Members": [
    { 
      "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/AccountService/Accounts/test"
    },
    { 
      "@odata.id": "/redfish/v1/AccountService/Accounts/root"
    }
  ],
  "Members@odata.count": 2,
  "Name": "Accounts Collection"
}
```
Not everything here worked as expected, please see inline.

Interesting;  I will take a look.

Just to make sure, this doesn't cause a user facing failure, because the UI doesn't support IsAuthenticated correct? (although we should make sure the behavior matches the intent, so I'll take a look either way)

> Just to make sure, this doesn't cause a user facing failure, because the UI doesn't support IsAuthenticated correct?

mTLS for WebUI wasn't working (requires normal logging in) before this change for the same reason and still doesn't work now with unmodified webui-vue. That's because before the app wants to route to `/` https://github.com/openbmc/webui-vue/blob/master/src/router/routes.js#L94 it checks if the user was authenticated https://github.com/openbmc/webui-vue/blob/master/src/router/index.js#L22 and since there is (and there was) no cookie https://github.com/openbmc/webui-vue/blob/master/src/store/modules/Authentication/AuthenticanStore.js#L22 the router redirects to `/login`.

If this check is relaxed webui-vue starts being functional with mTLS (of course without WebSockets). My guess is that if the cookie was actually set webui-vue would work without changes but I haven't tried. I'd say webui-vue supported and still supports isAuthenticated cookie but bmcweb stopped sending it after some regression and that's why mTLS for webui-vue stopped working.
